abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability highly likely, and institutional development
            impacts are high. The primary lesson indicates that
            expanding EMAF (Export Market Access Fund)-like
            public-private partnerships for effective export development
            is more effective than purely public, and centralized
            support. EMAF clients now pay half of the technical
            assistance costs of export business development services,
            and, surveys reflect that 60 percent are ready to cover the
            full costs of export consultants. This demand-driven
            approach has also simultaneously helped stimulate a new
            local market of business development services, focused on
            the export market. Success of this partnership depends upon
            a delicate balance of public policy and financial support,
            and a light, flexible and efficient private sector-like
            program execution. The balance achieved in EMAF is essential
            for the success of subsequent operations, and other such
            programs. Notwithstanding, it is emphasized that a strong
            and credible management team, cultivating good relations
            with financial institutions is critical for schemes such as
            the Pre-shipment Export Finance Guarantee (PEFG), that serve
            as catalyst to address export financing constraints. Proper
            promotion and marketing of the scheme is as important. For
            PEFG-like schemes to succeed, key non-performance risks
            should be addressed: the survey conducted among firms and
            banks, confirmed that the instrument is needed, useful, and
            effective, but it will not work unless the bad-faith issue
            is addressed. Further lessons reinforce the importance of a
            strong Government commitment, of collaboration and
            coordination among the various agencies, of an established
            trade regulatory framework, and, of simplified factors for
            trade facilitation.

5086084.trustfund:
TF039371-ALGERIA - FIRST PRIVATE
            ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039355-TUNISIA - EXPORT DEVELOPMENT,TF036770-MOROCCO - TELECOM ADJUSTMENT
            LOAN PROJECT,TF037952-TUNISIA - EXPORT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF037099-TUNISIA - EXPORT DEVELOPMENT,TF038684-TUNISIA:  EXPORT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF025327-PHRD-EXPORT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
5086084.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Trade and integration

abstracts.cdata!:
The Export Development Project seeks to
            enhance the ability of Tunisian private exporters to
            integrate into the global economy. The project will foster
            export competitiveness of Tunisian firms by mitigating some
            of the disadvantages they encounter relative to their
            foreign competitors. There are three project components. 1)
            Export market access will include a grant fund to cover on a
            temporary basis up to 50 percent of the cost of consultant
            services required to enable enterprises to enter export
            markets. The component will offer its services solely in
            response to private sector demand on a
            first-come-first-serve basis. 2) Preshipment export finance
            guarantee will encourage financial institutions to provide
            preshipment financing to small enterprises medium
            enterprises and emerging exporters with viable export
            contracts whose perceived nonperformance risk is greater
            than their actual risk because they are unable to provide
            adequate collateral or do not have a suitable credit history
            to prove that they are creditworthy. 3) Trade facilitation
            component will support investments and technical assistance
            required to reduce the number of procedures and transaction
            costs involved in trading activity, with special emphasis on
            customs procedures and electronic exchange of trade-related documents.
